sentence: Detailed results can be found in Table 4 and Figure 1.
Figure 2 illustrates the association between controllable variables and infection probability across various exposure durations.

Figure 2 displays that, in any case, the infection probability curve was black, pink, blue, and orange, from top to bottom, representing activity levels and breathing types of light activity, singing/speaking loudly; heavy exercise, oral breathing; light activity, speaking; and resting, oral breathing, respectively.

Using Figure 2A(a) as a reference, in the case of poorly ventilated, unvaccinated (or without previous infection), without wearing a mask and exposure for 3 h, the probability of infection in the combination of four activity levels and breathing types was 92.97%, 60.2%, 30.39%, and 8.04%, respectively, which indicated that, in the place of light activity and speaking/singing loudly, the probability of infection for contacts was as high as 90%, significantly higher than the probabilities associated with other combinations of activity levels and breathing types.

The data presented in Figure 2 demonstrate that the probability of infection for contacts in a given setting was consistently higher when masks were not worn, as indicated by the solid lines consistently above the dashed line.

Specifically, under the conditions of Figure 2A(a) with an exposure time of 0.5 h, the probability of infection for various activity types and breathing levels was approximately twice as high without masks compared to with masks.

In Figure 2A(a), taking light activity, singing/speaking loudly had the highest probability of infection; as an example, when ACH = 0.5, without a mask, exposure time of 3 h, unvaccinated, the probability of infection was 92.97%; when ACH = 3, the probability of infection was 35.90%; when ACH = 10, the probability of infection was 12.05%.

Taking light activity, singing/speaking loudly, as an example, Figure 2A(a),B(a) shows that when poorly ventilated, without masks, and with an exposure time of 3 h, the infection probability of contacts of vaccination (or previous infection) was 72.00% and the probability of infection was 92.97% for those who were not vaccinated.
Detailed results can be found in Table 4 and Figure 1.
